home.heroTitle: Digital Evidentiary Preservation with Verifiable Chain of Custody
home.heroSubtitle: Technological infrastructure dedicated to the structured and chronologically documented organization of digital assets with potential evidentiary relevance under Brazilian law, supported by verifiable chain of custody mechanisms and technical integrity controls.
home.introTitle: How to Preserve Digital Evidence Under Brazilian Law
home.introP1: Digital evidence preservation consists of the structured and chronologically documented organization of digital assets with potential evidentiary relevance, ensuring that their integrity may later be technically verified by a competent authority.
home.introP2: This infrastructure operates primarily in the pre-litigation phase, organizing digital records before judicial, administrative, or arbitral proceedings are initiated, contributing to greater procedural predictability.
home.introP3: The admissibility and evidentiary weight of preserved assets remain exclusively subject to the assessment of the competent authority under Brazilian procedural law.
home.pillar1Desc: Structured chronological recording of events related to the digital asset, enabling technical reconstruction of its documentary history.
home.pillar2Desc: Technical identification and registration mechanisms allowing future verification of integrity without exposure of the preserved content.
home.pillar3Desc: Possibility of notarial deed issuance based on previously preserved assets, upon request by the holder.
home.h2Main: Technical Organization of Evidence with Evidentiary Validity
home.h2Secondary: Infrastructure Founded on Brazilian Code of Civil Procedure

preservation.title: How to Preserve Digital Evidence with Integrity and Documented Chain of Custody
preservation.p1: Preserving digital evidence requires technical mechanisms capable of recording chronological events related to each asset, ensuring verifiable integrity over time.
preservation.p2: The digital chain of custody documents events such as deposit, integrity registration, and controlled access by the holder, allowing structured historical reconstruction.
preservation.p3: Organized evidentiary documentation may support future judicial, administrative, or arbitral proceedings under Brazilian law, without constituting automatic legal validation.

legalBasis.title: Legal Basis for Digital Evidence Preservation under Brazilian Law
legalBasis.p1: Brazilian law recognizes documentary evidence in electronic form, provided that its integrity and origin can be technically demonstrated in accordance with procedural principles.
legalBasis.p2: Structured digital records may contribute to the formation of judicial or administrative conviction when submitted to competent authority analysis.
legalBasis.p3: Upon request of the holder, a Brazilian notarial deed (ata notarial) may be issued to formally document the existence and chronological preservation of the asset.
legalBasis.h2Main: Legal Basis for Electronic Evidence Admissibility
legalBasis.h2Secondary: Brazilian Legislation Applicable to Digital Evidence
legalBasis.h3CivilProcedure: Code of Civil Procedure — Articles 369, 422, and 439
legalBasis.h3DigitalSignature: Provisional Measure 2,200-2/2001 — ICP-Brasil and Digital Signature
legalBasis.h3LGPD: Law 13,709/2018 — Data Protection and Evidentiary Preservation

security.title: Integrity Architecture Applied to Digital Evidentiary Preservation
security.p1: Digital assets are protected by encryption and authentication mechanisms linked exclusively to the holder's Brazilian digital certificate, restricting access solely to the depositary.
security.p2: No content is accessible to third parties, including the infrastructure operator, ensuring strict confidentiality and preservation integrity.
security.p3: Complementary integrity verification records may be generated without exposing the preserved content itself.

howItWorks.title: How It Works
howItWorks.step1Desc: The process begins with structured identification of the holder, which may involve Brazilian notarial validation when applicable.
howItWorks.step2Desc: After authentication, the digital asset is deposited and submitted to technical integrity registration.
howItWorks.step3Desc: All subsequent actions become part of a documented digital chain of custody.
howItWorks.step4Desc: Access remains exclusively under the control of the holder through Brazilian digital certificate authentication.

government.content: Public institutions generate digital records that may be used in audits, administrative investigations, and formal proceedings. Prior technical organization contributes to documentary governance and institutional predictability.

companies.content: Companies may structure digital evidence prior to litigation or internal investigations, contributing to compliance frameworks and legal risk mitigation.

individuals.content: Individuals may preserve digital documents with potential future legal relevance, organizing evidence in advance of possible disputes.

institutional.title: Institutional Structure
institutional.p1: Tutela Digital® is a technological infrastructure for digital evidentiary preservation developed under structured legal foundations and verifiable technical mechanisms, operating exclusively under Brazilian law. The company acts solely in the technical organization and structured preservation of digital assets, with documented chain of custody, cryptographic integrity, and immutable time registration. The admissibility of evidence remains always subject to evaluation by the competent authority under Brazilian law, with the infrastructure acting on technical preservation rather than legal valuation of the preserved content.
institutional.p2: Holder identity validation occurs through notarial interview conducted by a competent Brazilian notary via the e-Notariado system, ensuring public faith and documentary authenticity from the origin of preservation. This procedure ensures that the depositor's identification is carried out with the same legal security standard used in in-person notarial acts under Brazilian law, constituting an essential element of the chain of custody and contributing to the evidentiary reliability of the preserved asset throughout the entire preservation cycle.
institutional.p3: Tutela Digital® does not provide legal advice, does not issue opinions on evidence admissibility under Brazilian law, and does not conduct merit analysis of deposited content. The infrastructure is limited to structured technical preservation of digital assets, with integrity mechanisms, traceability, and authorship control. The decision regarding the use of preserved assets, their evidentiary relevance, and procedural strategy rests exclusively with the holder or their legal counsel, with admissibility remaining subject to analysis by the competent Brazilian judicial authority.
institutional.p4: The admissibility and evidentiary value of preserved assets depend exclusively on the assessment by the competent authority under Brazilian law, according to the specific circumstances of each case and applicable legislation. Tutela Digital® does not replace notarial activity under Brazilian law and does not exercise jurisdictional functions. Upon request by the holder, assets may be submitted for notarial formalization through a Brazilian notarial deed at a competent notary office. The applicable legislation for digital evidentiary preservation and electronic evidence admissibility is Brazilian legislation, including the Code of Civil Procedure, Law No. 11,419/2006, Provisional Measure No. 2,200-2/2001, and Law No. 13,709/2018 (LGPD).
